social_posts.post_text:
Join us for one last year at the Tucson Show! We'll have a limited selection of the exceptionally preserved pyritized trilobites with legs & antennae from Wednesday, January 26 until February 6, or until the trilobites are gone.  If you can't get to the show you can browse the exclusive Tucson inventory on @fossilsoup website, available starting Jan 26th (link in bio). 
#fossils #fossilsforsale #trilobites #palaeontology #geology #tucson #tusconshow #arizona #tucsonshowfossils
Jump over to the @fossilsoup website to view our exclusive Tucson Show inventory! Link in bio!  #fossils #paleontology #dinosaur #trilobite

Stunning Modocia typicalis trilobite with some interesting spine pathology from the Middle Cambrian rocks of Utah. Classic deep bowl prep done by @fistfuloffossils #trilobite #utah #paleontology #fossils

Incredible preservation of the trilobites of Beechers Trilobite Bed.  This stunning ventral specimen is absolute perfection. The ventral soft tissue anatomy is absolutely incredible. #trilobite #fossils #paleontology #geology #newyork

A huge 9cm, 510 million year old raptorial appendage from a radiodont (anomalocarid) arthropod, nestled amongst a group of Elrathia trilobites from Utah.  It is most likely from a large Hurdid, a close relative to it more famous cousin, Anomalocaris (see last image). Radiodonts are the original super predator, being the first known large predators in the fossil record and the clade likely endured from the Lower Cambrian through the Devonian Periods, approximately 150 million years.  Radiodont frontal appendages, like the one above, evolved an incredible array of diverse designs for specific uses from predator to filter feeder.  This one is clearly predatorial.  The original animal that carried this large arm would have likely been several feet in size! #anomalocaris #hurdia #fossil #paleontology #fossils #utah #cambrian #predator #geology #marinebiology #earth #history

A classic Burgess Shale arthropod, Isoxys acutangulus, but from the Middle Cambrian rocks of Utah, preserved in vivid red. Isoxys was a swimming predator with a sharply pointed, bivalved carapace.  Normally only empty carapaces are found as fossils, but occasionally the whole animal is preserved as in this case.  At least one eye and the two raptorial appendages this little arthropod used to capture prey are preserved. Showing through the carapace are some internal segments and other soft tissue bits.  The Isoxys is situated on a plate with two upside down Elrathia trilobites, bot molts, missing their free cheeks.  Just to the top left of the isoxys is the faint remnant of an Anomalocarid head shield, likely from Hurdia or Pahvantia.  This is a rare and stunning plate with it’s red preservation!  #isoxys #paleontology #geology #paleontologist #cambrian #utah #marinebiology #fossils #extinction #extinct

The stunning golden trilobites of the historic Beecher’s Trilobite Bed in New York. If you look closely you can see legs and antennae on the trilobites. Such beautiful fossils!
#trilobite #fossils #paleontology #geology #marinebiology #newyork #arthropods #fossil

At nearly 510 million years old, this trilobite species from Utah is legendary for its rarity and standing rack of back spines. This 8cm example of Olenoides nevadensis is part of an increasingly hard to find Cambrian fossil fauna.  It’s close cousin Olenoides serratus is a better know species from the Burgess Shale fauna.  #trilobite #trilobites #fossil #fossils #utah #paleontology #paleo #geology #rocksandminerals #nature #naturalhistory #arthropod marine biology

The rare trilobite Kochiella sp. from Middle Cambrian period (510 million years old) from the Groom mountain range in Nevada.  This area is often referred to as “Area 51” due to its close proximity to the actual Groom Lake installation known as Area 51.  Just a few miles from the secret airstrip is an incredible fossilized  marine fauna spanning the Lower to Middle Cambrian period. This trilobite in particular is rarely found, and generally found in pieces and parts. It’s tail features interesting twin flaps resembling an upside down heart. #trilobite #trilobites #nevada #area51 #groomlake #paleontology #geology #paleo #fossils

Massive example of the trilobite species Asaphiscus from the 500 million year old rocks of Utah.  Preserved in vivid colors, this individual is quite large for this species measuring just under 8cm (3 inches). Trilobites from the Middle Cambrian of Utah sometimes preserve phosphatized internal gut traces.  The internal gut traces are preserved on this specimen but strangely have been fossilized 3 dimensionally on the outside of the carapace (see last photo for highlighted gut trace). This is one of the best examples of this species I have ever seen and more impressive in person.  #trilobite #fossils #paleontology #geology #utah #cambrian #marinebiology #fossil #earlylife

The enigmatic fossilized carpoid from the Late Ordovician (450 million years old) from the historic Beecher’s Trilobite Bed in New York.  These strange marine animals were echinoderms, a relative of sea stars and crinoids.  At one point carpoids had been considered as a part of a stem group of chordates (vertebrates), however it’s likely that is not the case.  This specimen, owing its exceptional preservation to the unique conditions found at Beecher’s Trilobite Bed, is likely the the best preserved example of this extinct group. Swipe for different lighting of the specimen. #evolutionarybiology #carpoid #fossils ##echinoderms #geology #paleontology #marinebiology #science #naturalhistory #nature #newyork

Fresh split on a cluster of fossilized trilobites from the historic Beecher’s Trilobite Beds in northern New York.  These golden beauties are quite large for the site and will all feature the incredible preservation action of soft tissues like legs and antennae the site is known for.  I’ve been spending less and less time at this site over the past few seasons as other projects have pulled me away.  Hoping to spend more time on site late summer and make more discoveries like this. #paleontology #paleontologist #arthropod #marinebiology #ordovician #fossil #fossils #trilobite #trilobites #explore #newyorkfossils #newyork #science #naturalhistory

A large maroon colored Glossopleura trilobite from the Middle Cambrian aged Chisholm Shale of Nevada.  The host rock is roughly 510 million years old, and while this formation is very fossiliferous it is far better known for its silver and gold content that was heavily mined in the 20th century.  The highly metamorphic unit produces an incredible array of articulated trilobites and echinoderms, with its main accessible sites generally occurring across several mountain ranges at or above 7,000 feet in southeastern Nevada.  The Chisholm Shale is best known for producing at least three species of the iconic and spiny Zacanthoides trilobites, this Glosspleura is an exceptional example in its own right.  Note the small axial spines on the lower thorax.  #trilobite #trilobites #geology #paleontology #fossil #fossils #nevada #marinebiology #ancientlife #pattern #rocks

A stunning and rare Naraoia from the Cambrian rocks of Utah.  This soft bodied arthropod rarely preserves anatomical detail as seen in this specimen.  Swipe for an inverted color view of the anatomy.  Naraoia was first discovered by American paleontologist Charles Walcott at the Burgess Shale site.  Its classification has bounced around as a presumed crustacean, a trilobite progenitor and now is currently recognized in Trilobita.  This particular individual is certainly among the best preserved and largest examples of this beast found in Utah.  It measures approx. 3cm with many appendages, both antennae and much of the circulatory system preserved.  #earth #ecosystems #trilobite #paleontology #geology #fossils #utah arthropod #fossil #marinebiology

Predation caught during fossilization? Maybe…This incredibly preserved Triarthrus trilobite is laying on its back with its ventral soft tissue anatomy preserved.  Its legs, antennae, gills, and other rarely seen parts of the trilobite are all preserved in golden pyrite.  More amazingly, caught in the trilobite’s mandible-like gnathobases just behind the mouth is an ostracod.  The ostracod, a tiny crustacean, is situated directly in front of the mouth opening, sitting in the trilobites mandibles.  There is a second ostracod tangled in the pygigidial legs behind the tail.  This may also be a chance association where they simply happened to be buried this way.  However we have recovered multiple specimens over the years with the same association.  An interesting mystery from 450 million years ago. #trilobite #fossils #paleontology #geology #newyork #ostracod #predator #predation #marinebiology #history

The legendary preservation of Beecher’s Trilobite Bed extends to more than trilobites.  A host of enigmatic creatures are also found at this historic site known for its pyrite preservation of soft tissues of animals that lived 450 million years ago.  This stunning undescribed arthropod is one of those.  It doesn’t look very friendly.  These arthropods are relatively rare in these rocks, suggesting they may have spent most of their time cruising the water column above the substrate rather than crawling around on the sea floor with the trilobites.  #trilobite #fossils #paleontology #geology #newyork #ostracod #predator #predation #marinebiology #history

Super spiny fossilized trilobite Koneprusia dahmani from the Lower Devonian rocks of the North African desert. One of the best ones I’ve seen! These spiny little beasts are a marvel of evolution and approximately 400 million years old! Hats off to the highly skilled fossil preparators of Morocco. Extraction from rock on something like this is no easy task and only a highly skilled technician using micro air-abrasion and micro air scribes can accomplish this feat. This one is 100% real and in the collection of my friend @trilobites4u #marinebiology #paleontology #geology #trilobites #trilobite #fossil #fossils #Morocco #africa #naturalhistory

A very glassy and colorful trilobite fossil, Crotalocephalus sp., from the Devonian near Jorf, Morocco. This rock has been around on the planet for nearly 400 million years, long before the dinosaur existed. During all of that time it wasn’t just sitting there in a static state. As continents move, rocks get subjected to all sorts of forces. The host rock in this case has been metamorphised, meaning the original sedimentary layers and fossils inside have been subjected to high heat and pressure, modifying their original structures and mineralogy. This partially melted rock is responsible for the glassy and colorful appearance of the fossils in the unit. Metamorphic processes often produce beautiful and strange things to happen to fossils. Stunning colors, translucence, luster and even stretching, flattening, and twisting can all occur leaving the remaining fossil heavily modified from its original form. In this case the metamorphosis has produced great aesthetics! In the collection of my friend @trilobites4u #marinebiology #paleontology #evolutionarybiology #geology #minerals #mineralogy #color #trilobite #trilobites #fossil #fossils #naturalhistory #fossilcollection #arthropod #rocksandminerals #art #artbynature #morocco #africa #dinosaurs

Insane perfect split on an insanely rare lobopod from the Late Ordovician rocks of New York.  Found in a new horizon that produces prolific numbers of rare Diagoniella sponges. The hammer strike that split the rock was extremely lucky, missing the lobopod by a few hundred microns! We’re still in shock over this split!!!!! With @crg656 #paleontology #fossils #ordovician #newyork #burgessshale

Insane preservation on this rare Middle Cambrian comb jellyfish from the rocks of Utah!  Also know as Ctenophores, these early ancestors lived over 500 million years ago, with their descendants numbering over 200 living species Alice today. Fossilization of these animals is extremely rare as they had a  gelatinous body like modern jellyfish. There is much interest in ctenophore evolution in recent years as their controversial phylogenetic position in the animal tree of life has prompted conflicting hypotheses. While some studies suggest they might represent the earliest branching animals, others suggest a more traditional position as close relatives of jellyfish.  This specimen measures 2cm. #jellyfish #combjelly #fossils #fossil #paleontologist #geology #utah #cambrian #paleontology

A massive enrolled fossilized Drotops trilobite from the desert of North Africa, now in the desert of Western Utah. Both of these arid regions contain rocks deposited from huge ocean ecosystems that existed hundreds of millions of years ago, but now rest in some of the most arid regions of the planet. A testament to the ever changing surface of the Earth. #earth #ecosystems #trilobite #paleontology #geology #fossils #utah arthropod #fossil #marinebiology

A quick publication on a rare echinoderm from Beecher’s Trilobite Bed from earlier this fall at the European International Echinoderm Conference. I’ll try to get this posted on academia.edu this week for download.  #echinoderms #paleontology #fossils #fossil #geology #carpoid #newyork
Exceptionally Preserved Fossils
